newsitem.title: RUSSIA: Best Russian shares slip, buyers look for value.
newsitem.headline: Best Russian shares slip, buyers look for value.

text.p: Most of Russia's best shares slipped on Friday in lighter trade as investors shopped around for value, but natural gas monopoly Gazprom showed gains, traders said.
The Russian Trading System RTS 23-share index fell to 329.97 from Thursday's close of 337.38 on a moderate total market volume of $37.70 million.
"Share prices are shaking into place a little bit," said Jim Nail, head of research at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell in Moscow.
"The market stabilised and consolidated and now investors are looking for relative value."
There were few bids for best shares like oil giant LUKoil and Moscow electrical utility Mosenergo, Trinfiko's Alexander Gritzkevich said.
LUKoil edged down to $14.82 from $15.15 at Thursday's close and Mosenergo slipped to $1.393 from $1.421. National telecoms firm Rostelekom nudged down to $3.930 from 3.990.
Grigory Pinsky, senior trader at Trinfiko, said Gazprom rose on Thursday's news that the company planned to purchase a 25 percent stake in national electrical utility United Energy System (UES).
Gazprom closed up at $0.680 from $0.627. UES slipped to $0.2280 from $0.2315.
"Only Gazprom was rising against the market," Pinsky said, adding he thought the uptrend would continue through next week.

Traders said Gazprom rose on chairman Rem Vyakhirev's published comments that foreign investors would be allowed to buy its domestic shares -- although many dealers were sceptical and cited later Gazprom comments that this was not true.
Oil company Surgutneftegaz ordinary shares also edged up, to $0.821 from $0.800.
